I really enjoyed this game, if you can get it to work it is a gem.

Pros:
Varied combat, nuanced and strategic.
Interesting and more mature story arc.
Engaging side content.
Character progression.
Large varied worlds.

Cons:
Technical issues out the wazoo.
Performance issues on almost every system.
The story is great, but it has some pacing issues.
Collectibles are primarily cosmetic and feel a bit lackluster.
Metroidesque backtracking (might be a pro if you like that sort of thing).

Better than the first in most ways. The stance changing is annoying, there are mods to fix it, I suggest using them.

Performance with a 9800x3d, NVME, and 3080ti @ 144hz and 2k res, maxed settings was 90% great. There were a few unexplained slowdowns from an avg 100fps to 30fps for a few minutes, then it'd switch back. Opening up the galaxy map on the ship tanks performance.

I completed about 90% of all collectibles and the entire story in about 25 hours. About a perfect amount of game as an adult with responsibilities.

The exploration aspect of the game is DEEP. You'll wander into a new area, which leads to a new area, which leads to a new area. It's all logical and very enticing. This game really achieves the "here's a huge map, with tons of details, go check out all the nooks and crannies for collectibles". This is by far the best aspect of the game.

Movement is good and interesting, getting around the map and unlocking shortcuts makes traversal fun. Fast travel is limited and handy but not too excessive that would lead you to do absolutely 0% extra exploration.

The combat is slightly harder than the first but only 1 or 2 required fights stand out with much difficulty.

I personally like the progression of the first game better, this game is mostly about upgrading your movement and gaining access to new parts of the map.

The story is well written, easy to follow, and character development is mostly logical.

Really akin to God of War with lightsabers.

Music and sounds are great, might just be Star Wars nostalgia.

Overall 9/10. All aspects of the game are performed well and it seems like the game was designed and coded by people who care, an atypical EA win. Some additional polish in progression, performance and design would make this a 10. Play it, it's fantastic.

[b]As of now this game is a really fun Star Wars game worth playing. That's the only good thing i can say [/b]

With how many frustrations i had while playing this, I ADVISE EVERYONE to buy this only on a discount.

When you get the last ability it's almost the end of the story ;//.

The amount of traversal sections WOULD BE good if they would've had improved feel of the movement. It felt really clunky at first, but it wasn't as bad in the end.

Review after playing through the campaign, which took about 31 hours.  TLDR, this is a game with a good Star Wars story that checks a lot of boxes.  While it does have its flaws it is worth picking up on sale.  This is the second game in the series, and yes I think you should play Jedi Fallen Order first.

 You should know that this game does use the EA app to launch through Steam.  The EA app does not allow steam family sharing.

Where this game really shines is in the story, and if you are into Star Wars stories this is a good one.  No spoilers, but this does pick up a few years after Fallen Order finishes.  There are a lot of references to characters in that game, so I think you should play it first.

The game itself as mentioned, checks a lot of boxes.  The cynic in me feels like that is what they were doing.  There's adventure game parkour, collectables galore, open world areas, loads of cosmetics and customization, metroidvania style backtracking, multiple saber stances, and parry focused combat.  A lot of that is done well.  I personally hate 3d level parkour but in this game the majority of it was pretty easy to do so I'm going to give that a pass.  As mentioned a lot of boxes are checked, but I think you would find better versions of those features in games in those genres.  It feels a little corporate.

The saber stance switching is pretty cool.  There are 5 stances in total.  I personally gravitated toward Cross-guard stance, Kylo Ren style, which feels like greatsword play in other games.  There's new force powers too which flow really well with combat.

As a negative, toward the end of the game the bosses all seem to have 3-4 phases with QTE's and cutscenes between each phase.  With the difficulty turned up you'll have to spend some time learning the fight and you'll have to go through all of that each time.  While the cutscenes are skippable the QTE's are not.  And each endgame boss has a lengthy grab attack animation if you get caught (seriously, I could put my controller down and look around the room while it was going on).  All of that makes having to repeat those end-game bosses a slog.

I did not encounter any bad bugs, but framerate slowdowns were pretty common.  They would happen when things were loading in more than anytime else.  Like, spinning around in a circle outside can make the game chug a bit.  I didn't encounter that in boss arenas where that would matter most, as those places are confined.

So yeah, pick this one and Fallen Order up on sale if you are looking for a good Star Wars story.

As someone who grew up watching all six Star Wars movies and The Clone Wars, but never played too many Star Wars games, Star Wars Jedi: Survivor was a surprisingly fantastic experience for me. It captures the magic, mystery, and adventure of the universe I’ve loved since childhood, and delivers it through an exciting, emotional journey.

One of the game’s strongest elements is its exploration. The worlds feel alive and rewarding to traverse, full of secrets, optional paths, and environmental storytelling that pulls you deeper into Cal Kestis journey. The story itself is amazing—engaging, emotional, and filled with memorable character moments that make the whole adventure feel truly epic.

The gameplay is a ton of fun as well. Combat is fluid and stylish, and while it can be challenging at times, that difficulty makes every encounter feel meaningful. The new rumour system adds a nice sense of discovery, giving you optional leads that encourage wandering off the beaten path. Overall, it strikes a great balance between narrative, action, and exploration.

That said, the game isn’t perfect. There are definite technical issues, including stuttering, performance drops, and the occasional bugs. In my case, most of the problems were just small graphic glitches, nothing major—but still noticeable. It’s the kind of game where the heart and ambition shine through, even if the polish is lacking in places.

Despite those flaws, I had a fun playing this one. It’s honestly way better than the prequel, and it reignited my excitement for Star Wars games in general. I’m absolutely looking forward to the next entry in the Star Wars Jedi series.

A flawed but incredible journey—and one that everyone should experience.

[h1]⭐ Jedi Survivor — Short Review [/h1]

[*] Incredible Atmosphere & Jedi Feel 

The game nails the Jedi fantasy: perfect saber feel, amazing sound design, and gorgeous environments. Visually and tonally, it’s one of the best Star Wars experiences. 

[*] Messy Combat & Weak Mid-Game 

The mid section drags hard. Too much platforming and open-world padding with very little story momentum. Combat often becomes chaotic due to endless small enemy packs — not quite Souls, not quite hack-and-slash, just messy. 

[*] Finale Completely Saves It

The last 5–6 hours are outstanding. The characters buildup —  story suddenly get sharp, emotional, and memorable. Easily the strongest part of the game. Overall a rough middle, but an incredible start and a phenomenal ending. Flawed pacing, great atmosphere, and some of the best Jedi moments in any game.

Amazing game, Respawn. Jedi Survivor is easily one of the best Star Wars games I’ve ever played. The combat feels fantastically smooth, weighty, and incredibly rewarding. The story is equally impressive: satisfying, emotional, and genuinely heartbreaking at times. I can’t wait to see where it goes next.

The amount of content packed into the game is impressive, and the metroidvania level design fits perfectly with the exploration focused gameplay. Humanoid enemies and bosses are consistently fun and engaging to fight. Customization for Cal is also a highlight. There’s a ton of variety and freedom in how you can shape his appearance.

For the next game, though, it would be exciting if lightsaber parts offered more than just cosmetic differences. Maybe subtle stat bonuses, unique effects, or small mechanical perks could make customization feel even deeper. It would also be great to freely swap between any lightsaber stance on the fly, with enemy encounters designed to encourage or even require certain styles to overcome them.

Now, for the negatives. Creature enemies and bosses really need some improvement. They’re often not enjoyable to fight, especially the Rancors and Ogdo bosses. Their attacks feel janky, their hitboxes are inconsistent, and the frustration outweighs the challenge. If one-shot grab attacks remain in the game, their hitboxes absolutely need to be fixed, or the moves should be removed altogether.

Overall, though, Jedi Survivor is an incredible experience, and I’m excited to see how Respawn evolves the series from here.

Star Wars Jedi: Survivor really takes the lightsaber-action formula to the next level. Combat feels smooth and weighty — you can actually feel the impact of each strike, and chaining abilities together is deeply satisfying. The game does a great job balancing intense duels with quieter exploration moments, letting you absorb the world rather than just rushing from fight to fight.

The environments are a huge highlight. From ruined cities to dense forests, every planet feels alive and distinct, full of secrets and side paths that reward curiosity. Story-wise, it continues the narrative in a way that feels meaningful, with compelling characters and choices that matter in small but noticeable ways.

Traversal is also satisfying: wall-running, Force-assisted jumps, and climbing make movement feel fluid, and the puzzles are just the right level of challenge to break up combat.

If there’s a downside, it’s that the camera can occasionally be tricky during fast-paced fights, especially in tight spaces. It’s not game-breaking, but it can be frustrating in a heated duel.

Jedi: Survivor is just BORING. When I say boring, I mean tedious and irritating, too. Imagine having powers and a laser sword, but instead of fighting, all you do is try to slog your way through pointless mazes, climb walls, or even climb maze walls, and then solve puzzles. Seriously...SOLVE PUZZLES!!! You never get really good or develop significant combat skills because, and here's the ugly truth, you DON'T use combat skills enough to be good at them!!

In action games, you use mostly combat skills with puzzle solving as "seasoning," a break from the combat to help "spice" up the game a bit. Puzzles are a touch of "something else" to make the games last longer and engage your MIND in a different way. But ACTION is the key. Combat requires a variety of techniques, with your fingers performing actions quickly and without much thought. That CAN'T happen if you're only doing it once in a long while. Reactions don't develop without a substantial amount of experience. Of course, you can use the training function, but even if you practice in the training function, by the time you get to an actual fight, the skills you practiced will be rusty again. That's how infrequent combat is.

In Survivor, you'd better hope you don't have to fight a Sith Lord because the only skills you've honed are how to use BD-1's little goop shooter and his slice dart shooter. OOOOOOOH. Exciting, I know! Also, you'd better hope there's a climbing wall you can jump to using a double jump, and then press B for an extra little zip. I mean, that's probably the best way to fight a Sith is to PUZZLE him to death, right?!?! Heck, partway through, you have to play as a completely different character. Fun right?! Wrong! You spend a lot of that time doing EVEN MORE puzzles!!!

Good Sith Lord!!! This game plays like the developers listened to overprotective mommies who complained that the Jedi were just too violent for their special little pookey-wookie and couldn't you make a game that's more cerebral for our little boys??? It's obnoxious.

I rage quit when I was trying to solve yet another puzzle, and instead of using Jedi powers or a lightsaber, I was squirting BD-1's black goop on the floor...again.

Heck, you don't even really play. You're just a character in a video. There's only one way to get through each map.
